question: In one of the hybridisation experiments, a homozygous dominant parent and a homozygous recessive parent are crossed for a trait. (Plant shows Medelian inheritance pattern)
choices: Dominant parent trait appears in <katex>$F_{1}$</katex> generation and recessive parent trait appears in <katex>$F_{1}$</katex> and <katex>$F_{2}$</katex> generations.
Dominant parent trait appears in <katex>$F_{1}$</katex> generation and recessive parent trait appears in <katex>$F_{2}$</katex> generation.
Dominant parent trait appears in <katex>$F_{2}$</katex> generation and recessive parent trait appears only in <katex>$F_{1}$</katex> generation
Dominant parent trait appears in both <katex>$F_{1}$</katex> & <katex>$F_{2}$</katex> generations, recessive parent trait appears in only <katex>$F_{2}$</katex> generation.
explanation: In a Mendelian cross (<katex>$TT \times tt$</katex>), the <katex>$F_1$</katex> generation is all dominant (<katex>$Tt$</katex>). In the <katex>$F_2$</katex> generation (<katex>$Tt \times Tt$</katex>), both dominant and recessive traits appear (3:1 ratio). Thus, dominant appears in both, recessive only in <katex>$F_2$</katex>.
